comments.text:
+Arreis235
 LOL!!!  You're just a superstitious little girl, terrified of death.  But 
I don't want to rock your faith in your New Age Fairy Tales.
When you have some scientific proof of an afterlife let me know.  Dreams & 
fantasies aren't "evidence."
The brain doesn't die when you're asleep, but if you're in a deep dreamless 
sleep, or under deep anesthesia, or I knock you over the head really hard, 
you'll be "unconscious" and unaware.  That's just like death -- nothing 
special. Oops?
And BTW, the ego, the self, the "soul" is also just a working "concept" of 
your "thinking" mind.  It's not real.  It doesn't actually exist.
When all thinking stops and you return to a state of pure consciousness or 
pure awareness, you'll know what Einstein & Watts are talking about.
comments.author: PlanetEarth Trimtab

comments.text:
+PlanetEarth Trimtab 

What are you so afraid of?. Do you believe you'll be bamboozled into 
believing some fake religion masquerading as science. Simply because it 
doesn't fit your perfect reality. Or rather the reality that's been 
explained to you thus far.

I assure you. You study the areas of reincarnation, metaphysics in micro 
and macro cosmic understanding. Frequency, Sacred Geometry. The first 5 
dimensions of reality according to our current understanding. Any book from 
Robert Monroe or his students relating to applying your psychic abilities, 
or rather cultivating them. Eastern understanding of Our Chi or energy 
systems. Perhaps do some research into Nikolai Tesla and Albert Eisenstein, 
both of which studied metaphysics, and both of which were interested in 
explaining that which we could not see, but from which we felt effects from.

Then you'll be ready to understand the first 2-3 episodes of spirit

what I have studied to understand spirit science. Can you say you've done 
the same amount of effort to understand ANYTHING in your own life?!?!
comments.author: Arreis235

comments.text:
+PlanetEarth Trimtab 

Well if you weren't so closed minded to NEW science, but rather a stick in 
the mud fan boy for the old science. You would have your answers.

Our consciousness doesn't effectively die when we go to sleep. Please 
refrain from regurgitating Old world information that in our current age, 
it is clearly outdated. You go to the same realm in which you die. This is 
why people can dream of the dead. This is the reason some dreams make 
sense, while others don't. Our level of understanding in that realm is only 
sparingly. For instance we have volumes of respected literature relating to 
dream meanings. In a dimension higher than our own home plane. You realize 
pretty quickly things don't work the same way they do here.

As with documented physic phenomenon, this information is subject to being 
taken with salt. But with such much volume and corresponding evidence to 
suggest my point of view is more correct, than yours. It isn't something 
out of this reality, to connect the dots, so-to-speak.

You claim no person has credible evidence, yet the sheer amount of evidence 
given from literally thousands of independent as well as group studies have 
shown otherwise. Had you actually watched the Spirit science video instead 
of bias'd rejecting it once you came across a subject you didn't understand 
instead of flat out rejecting it, in regards to my approach of researching 
independently in the event I don't know or can't understand something. Much 
the same way children look up words they don't know in a dictionary.  

I'll admit our level of information with this given subject is lacking, but 
with nay-sayers like yourself. How do you expect the given field to evolve 
in the same fashion as the other fields of science and understanding.

So I don't get this, you accept the universe is energy. Yet your unwilling 
to accept your soul is apart of that energy and thus resonates with the 
matter that creates your body. Our soul is essentially the magnet field in 
which the "metal shavings" of our cellular structure is aligned too. It is 
essentially the life force with which our bodies power themselves. Aside 
from food intake for bodily maintenance
 
So how do you suggest I spend my days. Like you or your ilk. Shopping, 
playing video games, and beatin' off to porn. Or logically accepting the 
accounts of thousands of people, some of which correspond in such a way, 
coincidence cannot fathom it.

----------------------------------------------------------------

If the age in which we lived was different, than I am Galileo, to your Rome.
comments.author: Arreis235

comments.text:
+Relativity Rok
Good one.  I also like the metaphor of bubbles on the ocean. 
We are all like bubbles of consciousness floating on the ocean of 
existence, the ocean of reality.  We "think" we're separate but we all came 
from the same ocean, return to the ocean when we pop, and are part of that 
ocean all the time.
Einstein said,  "A human being is a part of a whole, called by us universe, 
a part limited in time and space. He experiences himself, his thoughts and 
feelings as something separated from the rest... a kind of optical delusion 
of his consciousness."
comments.author: PlanetEarth Trimtab

comments.text:

comments.author: Relativity Rok

comments.text:
+Relativity Rok
Death is really not so mysterious.  Our consciousness effectively dies 
every night while in deep, dreamless sleep. Then in the morning we wake-up 
and are reborn.
Physical death is the same, except we don't wake-up.  We are the same in 
death as we were before we were born.  Where were you before you were born?
 
BTW, no one can prove an afterlife, because there is no credible evidence.
Also, no one can prove there's no afterlife, because you can't prove a 
negative.
(I can't prove to you there is “no” Santa Claus or tooth fairy either)

We are never separate from this cosmos, any more than a tree is separate 
from the earth, the sun, or the rain. 
We are everything & everything is us.
And YOU are actually 13 billion year old stardust become AWAKE! 
So, don't blow it. We don’t have much time to appreciate it.
comments.author: PlanetEarth Trimtab

comments.author: Arreis235

comments.text:
+Arreis235 There most certainly is a lot of truth in your first comment. 
Why are we afraid of our existence after death? What makes it so mentally 
fearful? I suppose it's the mystery of it all :) What might matter most may 
be the meaningfulness of the present moment. What we do, think, feel.

The definition of things being in black and white terms is interesting 
though. Is there anyway to truly know something without its opposite? Like 
darkness implies light, back implies front, crescendo and descendo.... yin 
to the yang. So really, are the to things separate to begin with? 

If a person really goes into question of death; and I mean gets right down 
to the nitty gritty. What does the question then become?....... What was it 
like before you were alive? Well that was when you were born :)
comments.author: Relativity Rok

I used to think there'd be no change the rate we're going (born into a 
corrupt system that has been going on for centuries). How the fuck do we 
crack that code if the information we have isn't complete and cannot be 
accessed? But upon doing some astrological research I think there lies a 
chance as we move into a new universal atmosphere (predicted by the Mayans 
and other ancient civilisations). All it could take is a huge type of solar 
wave to activate the 97% of our "junk" DNA, and change happens in an 
instant. But we have been warned to be loving, not hating, for when that 
time comes - basically like a catipillar becomes a butterfly it's coming 
close to our time where we will have free energy and have access to various 
conciousness'. But as I say, the way we treat each other is the deciding 
factor in humanity's survival or destruction.
comments.author: therealist811

comments.text:
Change is not about an abrupt u-turn, it's a slow process and it's 
happening right now.
There is no need to be cynical because it doesn't benefit anybody. Not the 
people around you and not yourself.

The access to information we and the next generations have is amazing.
Never in the history of the world was it this easy to become conscious of 
the world around us.
And with consciousness comes empathy and a new formed morality.

If you are cynical, look at past generations and how easy it was to lie to 
them and control them, things are changing, people are waking up, mainly 
because of the internet.

Again, it's not about an abrupt change in our lifetime, it's all about our 
children and the future of our species and planet earth.

Like other people referred to, Ghandi said it: "Be the change you want to 
see in the world". And ofcourse change starts with yourself.
It's really  that easy, and I don't want people to be cynical so therefore 
I am not cynical.

comments.author: Jamie B

comments.text:
+YourMajesty143 Yes, and the Egyptian and Libyan revolutions were 
horrendously violent and many, many died. That was my point.  Obviously, 
revolutions happen but to compare Britain/America with corrupt 
Middle-Eastern states and say "well it happened for them so it could happen 
for us" is, frankly, absurd.  

The Icelandic "revolution" is a topic of huge debate and it's very hard to 
find objective news sources reporting on the subject.  Google only comes up 
with a host of biased, left-wing articles. I'm not denying that people went 
to the streets and forced the resignation of leaders but this happened over 
the period of 5 years and many people claim that the situation now is even 
worse and that the "changes" effected by the people haven't worked. 
 Regardless of the details, we have to remember that Iceland was hit worst 
by the financial crisis and most of their banks went totally bankrupt.  It 
is a nation with a, relatively, very small population and is is not part of 
the EU.

Here, in Britain, the economy is recovering and there is just not the 
stimulus anymore for widespread protests etc; not to mention that we have a 
powerfully entrenched political system with an unwritten constitution. 
There is no way a group of normal people could waltz into the House of 
Commons and draft a new legally binding constitution.  In America, the 
unavoidable obstacle to a peaceful revolution is obviously the availability 
of guns - it is fanciful to suggest you could topple the US government and 
re-write the constitution without killing a hell of a lot of people.

I'm not trying to be a depressing kill-joy; I'm just realistic.  A 
revolution of "hearts and minds" is one thing but a peaceful political 
overthrow that actually works? It's fantasy stuff.
comments.author: Jamie B

comments.text: +Jamie B A like wasn't enough for how much I appreciate this comment.
comments.author: Mr Wizdumb

comments.text:
I'm happy to say that you're wrong. The only thing people ever do is 
change, in fact change is the one thing that will never stop to exist in 
this world. Everything evolves and transforms, always. There has never 
existed a phenomenon that does not evolve frequently. Humanity is and 
always will be changing, that is how nature works.

Granted, there will always be naysayers and those who try their best not to 
become more enlightened but in the end we all will, if not in this life 
then the next. Our step forward is inevitable, progress is natural. Nature 
has a way of getting rid of unnecessary setbacks. We will probably not live 
to see the whole world change but in our lifetime there will most 
definitely be enormous spiritual evolution in mankind. These alterations 
will be in step and rhythm of all the other enormous changes that are 
occurring, like science and technology. I'm happy to say that change is 
inevitable, nature proofs me right.
comments.author: CigaretteCactus

comments.text: be the change you want to see in the world
comments.author: openscorpionmind

comments.text:
The biggest revolutions in our world were sparked by one individual. It 
only takes inspiration to get the masses going.

“Never forget that you are one of a kind. Never forget that if there 
weren't any need for you in all your uniqueness to be on this earth, you 
wouldn't be here in the first place. And never forget, no matter how 
overwhelming life's challenges and problems seem to be, that one person can 
make a difference in the world. IN FACT, IT IS ALWAYS BECAUSE OF ONE PERSON 
THAT ALL THE CHANGES THAT MATTER IN THE WORLD COME ABOUT. So be that one 
person.”
― Richard Buckminster Fuller

“Few will have the greatness to bend history itself, but each of us can 
work to change a small portion of events. It is from numberless diverse 
acts of courage and belief that human history is shaped. Each time a man 
stands up for an ideal, or acts to improve the lot of others, or strikes 
out against injustice, he sends forth a tiny ripple of hope, and crossing 
each other from a million different centers of energy and daring those 
ripples build a current which can sweep down the mightiest walls of 
oppression and resistance.”
― Robert F. Kennedy
comments.author: YourMajesty143

comments.text:
+Jamie B

overthrowing leaders & governments like in Egypt & Libya, among other 
countries. Most recently, Iceland overthrew their entire government & used

from happening again. It hasn't been reported for a very simple reason:

comments.text:
+zeekthe hammer "when someone KNOWS something its very hard to get them to 
see other views other than their own" - this is what you stated. We tend to 
talk about ourselves when we try to give general and fair opinions. All it 
takes is for everybody to try their best to change. Do your little part. 
You don't need to change the world because it is hard enough to change 
yourself. If we all grow to feel strongly about our planet and the way it 
is run, we can create a revolution and it doesn't have to involve violence. 
If we sit and do nothing because we believe "it won't happen", then yes, it 
will happen but at a much slower pace. It is when you decide with yourself 
that you want this change that it will shake the foundations of other 
people's beliefs and it will make them question their beliefs. The answers 
will come to us but we need to start somewhere and I think Russell is off 
to a good one :) I know people who are constantly compassionate to all 
sorts of people. It is possible. It takes practice to stop judging 
ourselves and then stop judging others, in this manner we learn that we CAN 
love one another freely and with as much compassion as there may need to be 
given. We do not need to set our needs aside. You cannot nourish people 
from an empty well. It is an obligation to yourself to nourish your soul's 
needs and then to help others fulfill theirs. Spirituality is not like a 
religion, it is a personal experience and 99% of the time, it involves 
raising the vibration of the planet to bring us back to our true divine 
selves. We can do this, be the change you want to see in the world said our 
dearest Mahatma Gandhi :) Blessings and love xxx
comments.author: Nicole De Leonardo

impoverished world? Hell no!! The spiritually awakened understand their

top_comment.text:
Revolution lol... so we're all going to give up our addictions to our drugs 
and technology, and stop perpetuating the looting of the cradle of future 
human life?  This means not making money or pursuing material wealth at all 
btw.  Talk is cheap, I do not see this happening.  The machine is raging, 
and people who live in an ideological bubble of privilege are talking about 
revolution while the world goes to shit.  Go anywhere in the third world, 
spend a month there and then tell me I'm wrong.  And while you're at it try 
propagating trends such as landfills, overpopulation, deforestation, 
patches of waste twice the size of Texas in the middle of the ocean, we all 
know the laundry list.  We can't even take care of each other, much less 
our environment.  In order for there to be even a GLIMMER of hope, from any 
kind of realistic standpoint, we would have to unite all world governments, 
and find a way to support a population of 8 billion without draining the 
planet of its resources.  In other words all power structures (not just 
America, but China, all of it!) would have to dissolve/sever their 
attachment to making money, invest in sustainable practices such as plasma 
arc waste disposal, wind turbines, solar power, clean renewable fuel 
sources.... none of which is very profitable..... there's a reason we 
haven't implemented these things.  Human beings have a sort of desperate 
tendency to overrate themselves... all of us work every day, and we view it 
as something we have to do to support ourselves.  But what we're supporting 
is a system that assumes an endlessly exploitable frontier of resources, in 
combination with steadily increasing demographics.  People talking about 
spiritual revolution and species-wide ascension might want to start with 
themselves, maybe stop pretending that everything's hunky dory and the 
shirt they just bought WASN'T made by some kid on meth making the 
equivalent of 2 cents an hour in a sweatshop.  If karma is real, then the 
life of an average American consumer is a complete karmic travesty by 
default.  We do not have a handle on this, and it irks me when people try 
to say that we do, or that we easily could.  This is a sinking vessel, and 
we're surrounded by sharks.  no lifeboats, no escape pods folks.... and 
even if we did get it together the sun will die/go supernova eventually, so 
who gives a shit﻿

comments.text:
Spirituality won't get us anywhere, our problems are not caused by 
technology, but by our limited understanding of the world. Why are some 
technologies not profitable? Because they are not cost effective enough 
yet, because we don't know how to get them to do more for less. If we knew 
how to produce cheap thin film solarcells or nuclear fusion reactors we 
would have access to nearly infinite energy, at least compared to current 
standards. With that we could get greenhouse gases out of the atmosphere, 
break down our wasteproducts and feed the world. With nanotechnology, 
synthetic biology and regenerative medicine we could actually grow machines 
and buildings, reengineer the biosphere away from starvation, suffering and 
death and produce more food than we would ever need. With understanding of 
artificial intelligence, brain machine interfaces and our own minds inner 
workings we could enhance our capacities in all areas and actually achieve 
something akin to the awakening of the entire biosphere. Waking up to the 
universe is fine and dandy, but to then confuse this state of mind with 
actual understanding of the workings of the cosmos and think of your own 
preconcived notions as revealed thruth is the hight of irresponsibility. 
Yes, you might have realised that we are one, but thats it, thats all you 
know. All those people revered as spiritual teachers made the same mistake 
of adopting elements of their own cultural backgrounds that were not 
actually based on an honest inquiry of nature.
comments.author: Lihinel

top_comment.author: Ricky909

comments.text:
What's important is what beliefs people start to prioritize. Like on one 
hand a religious person can emphasize the more hateful/dividing aspects of 
his/her religion, but could also emphasize the harmoneous/loving aspects of 
his/her religion. In the end what it comes down to is that we as humanity 
built so much context/story to our beliefs and give it such a big emphasis 
that we refer back to old beliefs and as such the status quo is perpetuated.

Once we really decide that we, the people living NOW, want to live in a 
better world, than we have to stop referring back to old mistakes, stop 
being so vengeful, stop fearing the loss of possessions, stop giving 
everything a label. Like "this thing right here is mine, this money is 
mine" or on the other end: "it can't be mine because it is of someone else".

The only thing we really control is ourselves and the rest should be used 
when Needed. Having a home where you can feel safe is important, but if we 
start trusting each others more, we will be more free to be home everywhere 
on earth. We have to lose this generalistic paranoia towards each other for 
whatever reasons we came up with, whether it is because of race, religion, 
sex, age, social status, money income, or even what patch of land we live 
on. When you really look at these terms, you see they are just words.

They are words, and if you put an inquiry to it, ask yourself what it is? 
You'll conclude they are just words. We can refer to thoughts, emotions and 
sensations. But they are just that.

We should remove the context and story to everything, otherwise we cannot 
take actions to the Now, but rather let the past or future determine what 
should be the outcome. A murder is a murder, it's results are suffering. 
There is not a single argument to say any kind of murder is a positive 
thing (unless perhaps to end someone's  suffering).

We should not make any compromise and always do our best to be positive. It 
may take time, and that's okay, but always give it your best shot, don't 
judge the result. The intent is most important.
comments.author: Michiel v. Tienhoven

top_comment.text:
WARNING!

If you are reading this then this warning is for you. Every word you read 
of this useless fine print is another second off your life. Don't you have 
other things to do? Is your life so empty that you honestly can't think of 
a better way to spend these moments? Or are you so impressed with authority 
that you give respect and credence to all who claim it? Do you read 
everything you're supposed to read? Do you think everything you're supposed 
to think? Buy what you're told you should want? Get out of your apartment. 
Meet a member of the opposite sex. Stop the excessive shopping and 
masturbation. Quit your job. Start a fight. Prove you're alive. If you 
don't claim your humanity you will become a statistic.

You have been warned...﻿
top_comment.author: elitedonk

what about the pope? Isn't that individualism?

top_comment.author: Sam IT

comments.text:
+7thBurbury   Good points, but I see the collective a actions of people as 
the "higher power".  You want justice to emerge?  Try to participate in a 
society that can sustain justice.  Same goes for all other positive 
qualities in our lives.  The problems with religions is they can also make 
good people do terrible things; it depends on the choice religion and how 
to follow it.  So, why not just focus on making the right decisions from 
the start?  Religions are mostly primitive distractions, worse than current 
celebrities.
comments.author: jfuite

comments.text:
haha yeah but celebrities are not alway the best to look up to cause they 
make society want to live up to unimportant expectations of ourselves e.g 
like how we look (so many people are depressed about their appearance) and 
money ( like money is the most important thing to be happy) and fame ( if 
your not popular, can create feelings of loneliness..etc) and i agree 
people like to have something to look up to...but celebrities ain't the 
answer...i'm not religious but i respect it a lot more now because it can 
make people a lot nicer and is an example of believing in a 'higher entity' 
(compared to believing in artificial things like a girl these days believes 
getting their nails done will solve the problem haha).
comments.author: 7thBurbury
